raw_text:
US box office set for record high
 
 Ticket sales at the US box office are predicted to break records this year, with figures expected to reach $9.4 billion, beating 2002's all-time high.
 
 Overall figures could be dampened by the lack of a Christmas hit like last year's Oscar-winning Lord of the Rings. Traditionally, ticket sales during the festive season account for 20% of the annual total. Although admissions have actually fallen this year, the predicted high is down to increasing ticket prices. According to Exhibitor Relations President Paul Dergarabedian, the average cost of a cinema ticket could be as high as $6.25 in 2004, compared to $5.80 in 2002. This year some of the biggest hits such as The Passion of the Christ and Fahrenheit 9/11 came from outside the major studios which are usually responsible for the key blockbusters.
 
 "Many of the films that did well (with audiences) are not necessarily the films that made a lot of money," said Mr Dergarabedian. He added that surprise hits had come from some of the more art-house offerings such as Napoleon Dynamite and critical hit Sideways. Sony Pictures, responsible for hits like Spiderman 2 and The Grudge, are expected to top domestic market share for the second time in three years, with $1 billion-plus in sales for the third consecutive year. Sony Pictures Entertainment vice chairman. Jeff Blake said: "We had a really diverse slate this year, and... certainly we pulled off one of the surprises with Grudge." Horror movie The Grudge cost Sony $10 million to make but brought in $110 million. It's the latest in a recent trend for Hollywood studios to back the upper and lower ends of the market, whilst ignoring the middle. Warner Inc are likely to end the year in second place on market share with around $1.25 billion, with Disney at number three.
llama3.2:1b: US box office set to break records with predicted $9.4 billion figures, down from 2002's high of $10.6 billion, due to increasing ticket prices and a lack of major Christmas hits like Lord of the Rings. Average ticket price could reach $6.25 this year, compared to $5.80 in 2002.
llama3.2:3b: US box office predictions expect $9.4 billion in ticket sales this year, beating 2002's high. The increase is due to higher ticket prices, averaging $6.25. Surprise hits like Napoleon Dynamite and Sideways contributed to the boost, as well as Sony Pictures' diverse slate including horror movie The Grudge.
gemma2:2b: US box office revenue is predicted to reach $9.4 billion in 2004, exceeding the previous record set in 2002.  Rising ticket prices are driving this increase, despite a potential decrease in admissions compared to last year. Notably, surprise hits from independent studios and art-house films have contributed to the strong performance. Sony Pictures is projected to lead domestic market share for the third consecutive year, followed by Warner Inc., and Disney.

Many films that performed well (with audiences) are not necessarily the most profitable, with some of the more art-house offerings such as Napoleon Dynamite and "Sideways" toping the market share for third consecutive years. Horror movie "The Grudge" cost Sony $10 million to make but brought in $110 million, its latest surprise hit in a recent trend to back the upper and lower ends of the market while ignoring the middle.

Figures could be affected by the absence of a major Christmas hit like last year's Lord of the Rings. Ticket prices are anticipated to rise to $6.25, up from $5.80 in 2002. Outside the major studios, films such as The Passion of the Christ and Fahrenheit 9/11 have contributed significantly. Sony Pictures is expected to lead with a third consecutive year of over $1 billion sales, while Warner Inc and Disney are likely to rank second and third respectively.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about US box office performance in 2004. Let me read through it carefully.

First paragraph: US ticket sales are predicted to break records with over $9.4 billion, more than double last year's record of around $4.7 billion. They mention that overall figures might be lower because of a lack of a Christmas film like the previous year's Oscar-winning Lord of the Rings. Traditionally, 20% of annual sales are from the festive season, but this year it's about 18%, down to 25%. Average ticket prices went up significantly from $5.80 in 2002 to $6.25 in 2004.

Second paragraph: The biggest films like The Passion of Christ and Fahrenheit 9/11 came from outside the major studios, which usually make key blockbusters. Sony Pictures is expected to take over second place with a billion-plus sales, more than doubling last year's $1.65 billion. Jeff Blake says they pulled off an "unexpected" hit like The Grudge.

Third paragraph: Reviewing recent trends, Hollywood studios have been focusing on the upper and lower ends of the market instead of the middle. Warner Inc. is likely to end the year with around $1.25 billion in sales, while Disney stays third at about $2.8 billion. There's also mention of other studios like Blockbuster and Universal, but their shares are shrinking.

Putting this together, I need to cover the record-breaking sales, the reasons behind them being lower than expected due to fewer Christmas hits and higher ticket prices, Sony's success as a major studio taking over second place, their surprise hit The Grudge, and how studios are shifting strategies. Also, mention the market share changes for other studios and the overall outlook.

I should structure it so that each main point is clear without too much detail, just enough to cover all key points. Maybe start with US box office record-breaking, then move on to sales trends, Sony's performance, The Grudge example, and finally the competition among major studios.
</think>

US box office ticket sales for 2004 were predicted to break records, hitting $9.4 billion, more than doubling last year's high of approximately $4.7 billion. Despite fewer Christmas hits compared to previous years, average ticket prices rose significantly from $5.80 in 2002 to $6.25 in 2004, affecting overall figures.

Key trends included the rise of "surprises" like The Grudge and horror films such as Fahrenheit 9/11, which came from non-major studios. Sony Pictures, known for major blockbusters, expected second place with sales exceeding $1 billion, more than doubling last year's $1.65 billion.

Warner Inc. likely ended the year in second place with around $1.25 billion, while Disney stayed third at approximately $2.8 billion. Other studios saw shrinking shares as major blockbusters declined.

Traditional ticket sales during the festive season are down by 20%, but admissions could be affected by higher ticket prices. The average cost of a cinema ticket could be as high as $6.25 in 2004, compared to $5.80 in 2002. Sony Pictures Entertainment and Warner Bros. Are expected to top domestic market share for the second consecutive year with around $1.25 billion in sales, whilst Disney is likely to end the year in third place on market share with around $1.4 billion.

However, this year's high is expected to be dampened due to the lack of a major Christmas hit like last year's Oscar-winning film "Lord of the Rings." Despite falling admissions over Christmas, analysts predict that ticket sales will reach an estimated $9.4 billion during the upcoming month-long holiday season. The increase in ticket prices could be attributed to increased demand for high-priced cinema experiences and may even result in a surge of revenue at major box offices this year.

This is because 20% of annual total ticket sales come from December, but admissions have dropped this year while ticket prices increase. Some of the biggest hits are from art-house films such as Napoleon Dynamite and Sideways. Sony Pictures Entertainment tops domestic market share for the third consecutive year with an expected $1 billion in sales due to a diverse slate, including surprise hit The Grudge, which made $110 million despite costing $10 million to make. Hollywood studios are also backing upper and lower ends of the market, while ignoring the middle. Warner Inc is second on market share with around $1.25 billion, and Disney at number three.

Warner Bros. and Disney are expected to follow in market share.
